answers.author: Roderick Wood
answers.text:
The City of Indian Wells operates two 18 whole golf courses with a large club house.  The city uses a Management Agreement with a private golf course management company to run all aspects of the golf operation including the Pro and the pro shop.  the Agreement outlines the standards of performance required and we do a minimum of quarterly formal inspections for compliance and have regular monthly meetings to review issues by the city or by the operator.  We are very satisfied with this approach to the golf operation.  We feel we get much superior results from this approach than attempting to  operate the courses our selves.  Golf operations is their full time business where it would only be one of many services and operations of the city and would only be one of the operations.  These courses are a major revenue source and need full time, undivided attention which would not occur if the city were operating the courses.

answers.author: Curtis Davis
answers.text:
Johnstown has a 9 hole municipal course.  It under a lease management contract.  The manager pays $25,000 to the city each year and a % of golf shop sales.  The rate structure is done to allow city residents a break in the membership fees.  All equipment is city owned and annually inventoried.  Certain reports are required after each golf season.

author: Brock Soper
text:
Just trying to gather some information about your public golf courses. We are in the process of reviewing our Golf Course structure and organization, and want to get some feedback from other cities in regards to your manner of operation.
What is the operational organization model that you use? (facility lease, management agreement, full self-operation, other)
Do you have a Golf Pro as part of the staff? What is his contract like?
How do you handle vending facilities and the pro-shop?
How do you manage staffing levels? 
Do you have any service-level agreements in place?
title: Public Golf Courses
